events.name: StackUp Clinic: Getting Started with Digital Payments
events.description:
Do you want to start collecting money digitally with your app? Do you wish you could do more than just buy buttons and payment links?
This presentation will introduce you to digital payment solutions, explain how digital payment works, and show examples of how digital payment can augment your app.
The workshop in this session will focus specifically on integrating with PayPal REST APIs using PayPal’s NodeJS SDK (please bring a laptop to follow along). Participants are expected to have prior knowledge of JavaScript and NodeJS.
 
Agenda: 

Evolution of Payments
Applications for Digital Payments
How do Payment Gateways Work?
Introduction to the PayPal Developers Sandbox
PayPal REST API Integration Workshop

 
Speaker: 
Vincent Lau is an adjunct lecturer of Stackup who teaches the Fullstack Foundation and Connecting Using APIs courses. He is also the Chief Technology Officer of Takatack Technologies, the digital commerce arm of PLDT (Philippine’s largest telco), as well as the Chairman of the Digital Commerce Interest Group of the Singapore Manufacturing Federation.
Takatack is a channel partner of PayPal, and it’s TackThis online store builder platform has many payment gateways pre-integrated (e.g. PayPal, PayMaya, AliPay, SmoovPay, Xfers, MOLPay, DragonPay, etc.), which sellers can easily enable at a click of a button.
 
Reserving a Seat:
Enter the promotional code that accompanies the invitation email sent to you to reserve a seat.

events.name: StackUp Clinic: Bitbucket Pipelines and PM2
events.description:
This clinic explores Bitbucket Pipelines and PM2 as Continuous Integration/Delivery tools. Built within Bitbucket, Pipelines gives you end-to-end visibility from coding to deployment, and lets your team build, test, and deploy from Bitbucket. PM2, on the other hand, is a production process manager for Node.js applications. It has a built-in load balancer that allows you to keep applications alive forever, to reload them without downtime and to facilitate common system admin tasks. PM2 also enables you to manage application logging, monitoring, and clustering.
Please bring a laptop to follow along.
 
Speaker: Nathaniel Currier
With an extensive background in both the technical and creative landscapes and nearly a decade of experience in cloud computing, Nathaniel brings unique insights into effective product development and scaling. Nathaniel has worked with with some of the world’s most prominent and successful brands across the United States, Europe and Asia throughout his career including McgarryBowen, Marriott, Nokia, Samsung, Google, General Motors, RedBull, Spotify, and MTV/Viacom. 
 
Reserving a Seat:
Enter the promotional code that accompanies the invitation email sent to you to reserve a seat.

events.name: Annual General Meeting 2017
events.description:
Thank you for your continuous support this year, it was amazing! It is now time for this year's Management Committee to ​handover to the new committee. We believe that there is no one better to help set the direction of the club, than the members themselves. Therefore, we will like to invite you to the final event of the academic year, our Annual General Meeting, 2017.

The programs are as follows:
1. Speech by President
2. Report on club activities for AY16-17
3. Tresurer's Report
4. Nominees' Speeches and Voting
5. Refreshments! :)
events.location: The Nest Theatre @ Innovation Centre, , Singapore 63

events.name: FH #134: NixOS and Row Hammering
events.description:
Welcome back to our last episode of Friday Hacks for this semester! This week we'll be having Peter over to talk about Nix and NixOS. Nix and its related technologies bring a radically different approach to server/container management and allows you to provision OS and software in repeatable and consistent ways. Also, if you're curious about row hammering as a means of exploitation, mentioned last Friday Hacks by Halvar, Vishnu will be sharing about it in detail in the second talk.

Title: (Programming your OS && ignoring state) == bliss

Description:
NixOS fundamentally changes how we approach servers, instances and infrastructure and it all comes down to a quirky functional programming language named "nix".

This talk covers some of the problems we can solve when we don't have to care about mutating state and how adding a real programming language to our infrastructure enables us to do things we couldn't do before.


Speaker Profile:
Peter runs a small managed services company called Speartail, is CTO of a local SaaS startup and runs technical consulting company C2P4 with a partner where they help companies kick their tech stack and development processes into the next gear. He is also learning the violin much to his neighbors frustration.

He's @peterhoeg in most places online.

Talk 2:
Row Hammer: Flipping Bits in Memory Without Accessing Them

Description:
“Row Hammer” is a problem with DRAM in which repeatedly accessing a row of memory can cause bit flips in adjacent rows. This talk will be describing how DRAM chips work, how the row hammer problem occured and finally how random bit flips in memory can be exploited into a privilege escalation attack.

Speaker Profile:
Vishnu Prem is a senior Computer Science student in NUS who’s involved with the coreteam of NUS Hackers and the Singaporean tech scene. In the last few years, he has worked on software engineering projects for Twitter, Apple & Uber.

Sponsors:
This event is kindly sponsored by NUS Enterprise.
events.location: SR5, Town Plaza, University Town, NUS, , Singapore

events.name: DataDive: SG Children's Society, SG Red Cross, O'Joy Care Services
events.description: Save the weekend! We're having our DataDive on the weekend of 7-9 April! What is a DataDive?  A DataDive is a weekend long event where non-profit organizations work alongside data science volunteers, developers and designers to analyze data to gain insight into their programs, the communities they serve and more. Unlike a hackathon, there is no competition and no winner; instead, everyone is working towards the common goal of helping the non-profit organizations be more effective at what they do. Check out the project statements for each organization below: Singapore Children Society  We want to use {survey data from professionals and the public} to {analyze cohort indicators and group differences at various levels} so that {Singapore Children Society can better understand the similarities and differences in Child Abuse perceptions}. Singapore Red Cross We want to use {Blood Donation Drive Data} to {analyze factors affecting amount of blood collected during a blood donation drive} so that {Singapore Red Cross Blood Donor Recruitment Programme can better understand these factors and improve the efficiency of future Blood Drives}.  O'Joy Care Services Established in 2004 by a group of social workers and professional counsellors, O'Joy aims to enhance the psychosocial well-being of the elderly, as well as their families.   We want to use {the Community Mental Health Intervention Team (COMIT) dataset} to {analyze anonymized client medical history treating the elderly at risk of or diagnosed with depression, anxiety and/or dementia} so that {O'Joy can better understand their clients' needs and plan their resources}. Special thanks to Expedia for being our venue sponsor! Schedule Friday, Apr 7th  7 pm: Doors open, sign-in  (we're on the 6th floor!) 7.30 pm: Introduction to Non-Profit Organizations and Data challenge8.15 pm: Meet and greet, team forming 9 pm: Close for the night It's a great chance to learn about the non-profits and their data, meet the other volunteers you'll be working and talk with others from our partner causes! Saturday, Apr 8th 9 am: Doors open, sign-in9.30 am: Brief review from Team leads, then data diving! 12.30 pm: Lunch 1 pm: Open Roundtables 6 pm: Dinner 9 pm: Everybody goes home for the night Saturday we'll start work on the data!  DataDivers will choose which problems they'd like to work on and form teams around their individual questions. There will be roving DataKind project team leads who will help advise on and manage the projects throughout the day.   Sunday, Apr 9th 9 am:  Doors open, sign-in 9.30am: Brief review from Team leads, then data diving! 12.30 pm: Lunch1 pm: Prepare presentation4 pm: Team presentations 5 pm: Another successful DataDive in the books! This is your chance to show the world what you have done with data, and for our non-profit partners to better understand what your team did! These presentations can be single or group work, but they can be no longer than 10 minutes each.  We want to give everyone a chance to speak, and get people out at a reasonable time.   Other items of note for the weekend Please do the following Docker setup on your laptop We held a DataLearn on reproducible research, so volunteers attending the DataDive can setup Docker needed for the DataDive. If you've missed the DataLearn session, you can watch the video here. Volunteers at all levels are welcome throughout the weekend. If you're already a pro, we're looking for some subject-area experts to help with project preparation and be resources throughout the DataDive.   Unlike a hackathon, the goal is not (necessarily) to create an app, and it is not a competition. Instead, the objective is to work with teams of experts to understand a difficult problem through data.  You could end up with a visualization, an analysis, some graphs, or even just some new datasets by the end of the event, and all of those are fantastic results! There is a Github repository setup to use for sharing code and analyses during the event. This will be our primary resource for capturing everything developed at the DataDive, so please use it for sharing and collaboration. You do not have to stay the entire weekend to participate in the event.  We hope that you will find a project you can dig into, but you are always welcome to come and go as you please. You do not have to work on the same project for the whole weekend.  Again, we hope that you will find a project to work on to completion, but if at any point you feel like you want to change simply let the DataKind project team lead for your team know. We do not provide any hardware or software for you to use. We'll have the data and some services set up (Trello,slack, Github), but otherwise you should bring your own laptop and come ready to use whatever data tools you like. What should you bring? • Your laptop + power • A water bottle to refill• Lots of energy and enthusiasm!  See you there!
events.location: Expedia Singapore, 6th Floor, South Beach Tower, 38 Beach Road, Singapore 189767

events.name: Future Fridays: What Lenses are We Wearing?
events.description:
We are always clearheaded and objective, right? With the right information, we can make good decisions, yes?

In this session of Future Fridays, we will be exploring the lenses and biases we may have as we encounter pieces of information, and experiment with ways to remind ourselves of our blind spots. (no spectacle-wearing people were harmed in the making of Future Fridays). 

Join community leaders, educators, entrepreneurs and other active citizens like yourself to design a product that can help others access facts, start conversations and make better decisions. Over the course of 8 weeks, we will deep dive into:
-How decisions are made
-Common bias in thinking and decision-making
-Sensemaking and storytelling with data

At the end of the series, the product we design will be exhibited in 2 HDB locations so we can share our insights.

If you care about civic education and the future of Singapore, start taking action today!

Please note that you will be signing up a series and not for individual sessions because the sessions are cumulative. We will be taking a break on 14 April for the Good Friday public holiday. The specific dates we will be running for are:
-31 March
-7 April
-21 April
-28 April
-5 May
-12 May
-19 May
-26 May

See you soon!
events.location: Sustainable Living Lab (SL2), 1 Tampines Street 73, Singapore 528704
